Award.AwardTitle: A Quantum-Eraser Approach to Heralding High-Quality Single Photons

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to devise high-speed single-photon sources that are single mode, wavelength versatile, compact, scalable, and room-temperature operable for use in modern quantum-optics applications. A fundamentally new approach for losslessly managing the spatio-temporal states of single photons will be developed using the concept of quantum erasers and its applications in various optical systems, including fibers and crystalline waveguides, will be studied in detail. The approach will be implemented in a fiber-based system to demonstrate a high purity, telecommunications band, single-photon source whose production rate is potentially orders of magnitude higher than the state-of-the-art single-photon sources of comparable purity.
The intellectual merit is to use quantum erasers made from quantum-frequency-conversion devices to accomplish three crucial tasks for heralding pure single photons in a single step: (a) eliminating inherent quantum correlation between the photon pairs, (b) losslessly tailoring the heralded single photons into the optimal spatio-temporal modes for use in various applications, and (c) boosting the single-photon production efficiency by the naturally-matched use of higher-efficiency frequency-up-conversion detection.
The broader impacts are: 1) it will develop an enabling technology for transitioning to practice many single-photon-based applications that otherwise will remain in a research laboratory, particularly those that harness the existing low-loss fiber telecommunications infrastructure; 2) it will be a cross-disciplinary research activity for the students and postdocs, whose training will span a bridge between the fundamental science of quantum optics and the classical arena of optical engineering, thereby providing them a competitive advantage in the global photonics marketplace.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is concerned with better understanding the physics and limitations of light sources that generate single photons. The type of single photon source we are investigating is a heralded single photon source, which generates photons in pairs and uses the detection one of the photons to indicate the presence of the other. Such sources have proven to be very useful, but when current methods are used to separate the photon pairs there is a reduction of the photon rate or quality (purity) or both. We investigate the use of nonlinear frequency conversion of the photons using engineered pump pulses to improve system performance.

We demonstrated the use of a fiber-based pair generation scheme that generates photon pairs with record high quantum correlations (at a given fiber temperature). We developed a quantum model that describes the pair generation process in fiber including effects such as background (Raman) noise and multi-pair generation and showed good agreement between the model and experiment. Next we integrated a nonlinear quantum frequency conversion (QFC) system into the detection system. The QFC allowed temporally gated time-bin selectivity, where preserving the quantum correlations of the photons required synchronizing the detection time (QFC pump arrival time) to less than 10 ps.

The system was expanded to allow QFC pump pulses that are engineered via an optical arbitrary waveform generator to allow for a high degree of pulse-shape control. One of two overlapping but independent (orthogonal) time modes could be selected for upconversion at each photon detector, and the resulting quantum correlations were measured. A full quantum model for this process was developed to optimize the pump pulse shape and to predict performance for different pump powers and pump-signal delays. The theory and data fit well indicating that our models include the salient effects. The results will be published in the open literature. The model can be applied to predict performance when using this technique as a heralded single photon generator. The system requirements to obtain quality performance for this application can thus be predicted.
